How We Work

We build complex adaptive systems. We get grants for trees that are forest-fire hazards. We bring them to a zero emissions saw-mill staffed by the formerly incarcerated students who can now gain work training along. We partner with community development organizations to give them additional support. Then the lumber they create is lazer cut to create desks. We then partner with school districts or community organizations to distribute desks and computers to kids in need.

Bridging The Digital Divide

Designed for Beauty

Our furniture designs were created by Greg Flishman, who has a permanent collection at the Smithsonian. The designs are flexible and allows a child to bounce around in it making it great for kinetic learners.

Providing children with specifically beautiful furniture is an essential part of our mission. If we care about our children we don’t want what’s cheapest for them, we want what’s best for them. Kids know this and it affects them. If they are given beautiful furniture it will increase their self-esteem by showing them they are worth having something beautiful. The beauty within the furniture brings out the beauty within a child. Once a child knows their own self-worth they can bring that beauty into the world. We call this “inner chi.” It is our desire that our furniture speaks to the inner chi of students and allows them to dream and imagine wondrous new possibilities. We bring beauty and creativity into the lives of children so they can grow to love it and be inspired to create it.

If you want to bring out the inner chi of your own child, Shop Now! Buy one for yourself and sponser one for a child in need.

Easy to assemble, disassemble and transport

Our innovative design allows furniture to fit together like a puzzle, without nails and screws. Great for people who hate or don’t have nails and hammers. Perfect for puzzle fanatics!

This also means it can be distributed disassembled and families can assemble them in their home! Because of this we have designed simple carrying cases where the pieces of the desks can be flat packed into something the size of an art portfolio.

The light plywood we use also means these carrying cases are lightweight! Not only do these aspects of the design making shipping cheaper and easier, it also means children’s workspaces can be portable.

Perhaps there isn’t enough room to keep a desk assembled all the time? Easy, assemble it when needed and take it apart when the extra room is needed! Maybe the desk is needed in a different location? Take it apart and put it in it’s flat-pack carrying case and it's ready to be transported!

It will even be perfect for implementing our SMART KID Initiative, where kids can meet in pods to get their school work done together.

Mitigating Wildfires

The Problem

There is currently an epidemic of Ponderosa Pine Tree death. Due to warmer winters and longer droughts caused by global warming the pine beetle and other diseases affecting the ponderosa pine have ravaged the ponderosa pine population. These dead trees are tinder for larger than ever forest fires that can wipe out the remaining living pines. This is hugely problematic for a number of reasons. Trees serve as a huge carbon sink, sequestering carbon inside of their wood. Everytime there is a forest fire or trees rot back into the soil that carbon is released again, contributing to greenhouse gases and warming the globe. People who live near these forests can also have their homes or lives destroyed by these forest fires. The destruction of these trees can also sometimes have drastic effects on the ecosystem around them. The animals dependent on the trees for shetler can die, or other plant populations kept in check by the pines could explode. More than that in some places these pines shade snow that falls on the tops of mountains preventing it from melting for a few months. Once this snow melts it makes up the streams that many species depend on. If the snow melts too early fish species may no longer have a habitat they are able to reproduce in, leading to long chains of destruction from the animals that depend on them for food.

The Win-Win Solution

There are rare times when problems and solutions stare each other in the face. Such is the case here. California forest fire mitigation efforts include grant funding to improve forest health along with biomass and urban forestry wood utilization. This project directly assists Cal Fire sequestration of carbon effort by removing downed trees near roadways in the emergency zon. We give the emergency zone beetle killed pine a second life as high-quality work-desks for students who would not otherwise have a study space at home.

We will be partnering with local public works departments, landowners, businesses, and citizens to remove and mill downed trees before the wood loses its quality as lumber. Logs which cannot be milled will be repurposed for particle board biomass wood chip gasification to operate the sawmill plants while reducing our waste and carbon footprint.

Work-Study Fellowships for Formerly Incarcerated Californians

Creating Jobs

Our ecosystem allows for many different possibilities, We will have opportunities for employment building towards production of​ ​millworks, design, manufacturing & producing wood products, crafting furniture and structures. We will provide paid fellowships for cohorts of 50 formerly incarcerated individuals to experientially learn while contributing to the community. Beyond that our mill will prioritize hiring formerly incarcerated students from Reedley college. We are giving individuals in our cohort a second chance to use their full potential the same way we are giving our trees that same opportunity.

Participation with the Ecosystem

After students have finished their fellowship they can get involved with other programs Enerchi plans to launch: They can request the desks they produce for themselves, they can be mentored by our Senior Volunteer Corps, or become a mentor themselves. They may even be eligible to reside in our transitional housing.

Partnership with Reedley College

Dr. Bernard Luskin, recently retired Chancellor of Ventura Community College District, will guide curriculum and California Community College relationships for our team.
W​e intend to offer dual credit and community based learning college classes to students engaged with our program at each of the participating universities.
Students will learn ​millworks, design, manufacturing & producing wood products, crafting furniture and structures, urban forestry, AI and beyond.

Partnership with Calvary Community Development Organization

Calvary Community Development Organization is our partner facilitating recidivism reduction skills and counseling and career services.

Zero-Emissions Sawmill

Carbon Free Power

We are partnering with All Power labs, a manufacturer of biomass gasification electricity generation equipment. We transform sawmill waste and residual branches and bush from the pine after production into biomass fuel.

VIA trucks will be leased and equipped for field operations which power portable sawmills to emergency zone worksite scheduled Trucks provide site power for electric chainsaws, charge batteries for portable electric saws and team requirements. Our Urban forestry operation will require a F650 min. equipped form factory for clean burning fuel option. This vehicle will operate by liquid natural gas (LNG) or Propane gas. Both are zero emission solutions.

We will ship completed structures by container or rail car.

The sawmill can be used to produce other green justice projects in our ecosystem in the future.

The Greener Option

Making use of this wood and preventing it from rotting sequesters carbon. Additionally, preventing new desks being made from plastic made up of fossil fuels further protects the environment.

Our design is also made purely of wood- without any nails or screws. This means the supply chain is simpler and requires far less resources and energy. We are creating a new green standard and system to make desks which we must use in the future as we are able to use less and less fossil fuels.

We hope our mission of combining environmental preservation and quality of life can communicate to the world the interrelatedness of these two things.

The Green Wall

Our facility will further our goals of carbon reduction and food justice through our 720 square foot Green wall. The Green Wall will provide clean oxygen indoors with an effect equivalent to 16 fourteen-foot-tall trees.

The Expanded Enerchi Ecosystem

Senior Volunteer Corps

Students will have the opportunity to advance their personal and career goals leadership potential and become a peer mentor over time. We will also allow admin at our community sites to make referrals for peer mentors who are new to the program. In addition to mentorship roles, we will have opportunities for older students to become instructors for younger students, with high school instructing middle school, college students instructing high school students, and professional volunteers offering instruction periodically. Developing ​intergenerational relationships to grow understanding of eco issues and mento​r work teams provide operational personnel. ​ This solution would provide these volunteers with an environment and tools to make their efforts more productive and meaningful. The deployment mechanism for these learning resources is a tree mortality area specific AI portal powered by IBM Watson that focuses efforts on greenhouse gas reductions in every activity. Web services resources and the​ plethora of stipend, paid and volunteers ​that serve as instructors, tutors and mentors. Teams of small groups run all operations delivering on tasks assigned. Computer desks, chairs made of redeemed trees will be made available to participants.

Transitional Housing

In addition to our student- focused programming, we are also pursuing $75/ $25 USDA rural utilities infrastructure match grants so we can utilize our nail-free, zero emission, recycled wood designs to develop 5,000+sq.ft. homes for youth who are aging out of foster care. On our timeline, limited production of structures would begin to be delivered in the second year of operations. -mde by sawmill -perhaps on sawmill campus

Creating Ecologically Diverse Green-Space

Outreach and community by-in is vital; therefore; we will be partnering with local television stations to announce tree plantings, community gardening events, and other efforts. Every tree we plant will carry RFID chips to document carbon capture, report, monitor data points & track growth Building Community. When a seed is planted in it’s biodegradable pot at the company's nursery, it will be accompanied by an RFID tag encoded with a unique ID number linked to the date and information about its mother tree.

In that way, when the trees are planted, the staff has a record of each sapling's lineage and can thus ensure they do not exclusively plant trees from a single mother tree in one area, which would reduce the forest's diversity and, therefore, the general health of the trees within it. The tags, which comply with the EPC Gen 2 standard, are read using a Convergence Systems CS101 handheld interrogator, and the data is then transmitted from the handheld reader to the company's back-end system via a Wi-Fi connection. That data is saved on HLH's Web-based database, using software the firm developed itself.

Through research, the teaching and learning communities developed will create new products based on testing and applicable uses for fencing, gardening containers, urban raised bed vegetable gardens, covered community spaces, outdoor seating, tables.

The Smart Kids Initiative

Safe, Mobile, Creative learning Spaces

The SMART Kids initiative comprises a combination of technologies and resources that create small group after school programs, homework help, internships, work experience across a spectrum of ages and skill levels in disadvantaged neighborhoods.

We will host learning spaces in creative flexible locations where youth will be inspired to visit. We plan to partner with locally owned restaurants as study spaces, many of whom are struggling to stay afloat due to halted or reduced revenue after the onset of COVID-19.

We would have small groups of students come in on a scaled schedule, using proper social distancing and hygiene practices. No set-up would be required of the restaurant since each student would bring their technology kit, equipt with their own personal lightweight desk and computer. We would pay the restaurant to supply snacks for the students, thereby ensuring that the business has a consistent customer base, and the students have something to eat.

The offering includes teams of small groups numbering four to twelve persons each. Every team is resourced with a complete technology kit, including computer workstations and desks all in their own carrying cases (total weight under 70 lbs.) that set up would cost between $1,100 – $2,500, subject to volume.

Ecological Education

Ecology education is tied into every piece of our programming, however, we also plan to provide Community Based Learning, work-study, and internship opportunities to Reedley College Forestry students to give them practical experience in their field, and build a base of skilled professionals who could potentially help sustain our operations post-graduation. Urban forestry is social forestry. Our team views this as an opportunity to demonstrate the mathematics and geometry of doing more with less materials and effort. We are applying the accumulated knowledge of how to build in harmony with nature using its design of natural structure processes as a guide. Ecology education includes planting trees, green walls, and designing and building vegetable gardens to provide fresh food to the community. The core of our project is California Community Colleges which serve Fresno, Madera, and San Francisco.
